p: The efflux pump is a protein found in the plasma membrane of the bacteria, and its major function is to prevent the entrance of toxic compounds into the cytoplasm [ 17, 123]. This protein plays an important role in antibacterial resistance that helps bacteria to survive. A major mechanism of antimicrobial resistance is increasing the expression of efflux pumps in bacteria, which will subsequently result in lowering the antibiotic concentration in bacterial cells [ 65]. The efflux pump of bacteria works to protect the bacterial cell by pumping a large amount of antibiotics out of the cells [ 124]. Recently, some studies have found that EO are able to inhibit the efflux pump of the bacteria, and the compounds present in the EO have many targets on the bacterial cells [ 125]. Therefore, the inhibition of efflux pumps is a vital target for EO and their metabolites [ 126].
